para.paratext: In Georgia, the attorney-client privilege is perhaps the oldest privilege recognized by the courts. Historically, Georgia courts have confused the areas of competency and privilege with respect to confidential relationships, including attorney-client relationships.[1] The concept of attorney-client privilege, which formerly appeared in four different Code sections,[2] has now been consolidated into one section; O.C.G.A. § 24-5-501. This statute retains the general privilege of attorney-client communication on grounds of public policy and includes the prohibition of an attorney disclosing any communications made to the attorney or his employee “pending his employment or in anticipation thereof” or any communications arising out of the advice or counsel he may have given his client; it also prohibits attorneys from testifying for or against his client about any matter, “the knowledge of which may have acquired from his client by virtue of his employment … or by reason of the anticipated employment of him as an attorney,” and provides that a witness may not be compelled “to make discovery” of their consultation with, or the advice given to them by, their professional advisors. None of the statutory changes impacted the interpretation of Georgia case law with regard to the privilege.[3]

While the privilege is not absolute, the courts are reluctant to waive the attorney-client privilege.[4] This privilege belongs solely to the client.[5] An attorney has no power to waive the privilege and cannot rightfully disclose confidential information arising from the attorney-client relationship absent waiver by the client.[6] The mere fact that an attorney discusses communications with others in breach of the privilege, without evidence that the client authorized those discussions, does not prove that the client waived the attorney-client privilege.[7] Inadvertent or unintentional disclosures of confidential communications will not destroy the privilege.[8]

A waiver of the attorney-client privilege may be express or implied.[9] Implied waivers of the privilege are subject to a two-prong test set out by Bailey v. Baker.[10] First, the court must determine whether the client intended to waive the privilege, and second, the court must determine if it is fair to assert the privilege under the circumstances. Thus, a client implies that he waives the attorney-client privilege when he charges his former attorney with negligence, malpractice, or other professional misconduct and the attorney may openly disclose communications with his former client to defend himself.[11] Likewise, an attorney is released from his obligation of secrecy if a habeas petitioner claims that he was not informed about consequences of a guilty plea.[12] This waiver of the attorney-client privilege is not limited to the attorney's testimony, but extends to documents and files in the attorney's possession that are relevant to the specific allegations of ineffectiveness.[13] “The Georgia Courts do not waive the privilege absent a showing of the client's intent to manipulate the legal system through the assertion of privilege.”[14]

Not all communications with an attorney are privileged, and the statutes setting out the attorney-client privilege are to be construed narrowly.[15] The rule in Georgia and most other jurisdictions is that the relationship of attorney-client must have existed at the time the communication was made, or the communication must have been made in anticipation of employment.[16]

The privilege exists as to communications in anticipation of employment, even if the employment does not in fact take place and the relationship of attorney-client is never formed.[17] However, for the privilege to attach, the consultation with the attorney must have been in his professional capacity. If the attorney is “raided at the curb-stone” for legal advice, the privilege does not apply.[18]

The scope of the privilege extends only to those communications that are intended to be confidential. This includes communication by the client as well as advice given to the client by the attorney.[19] Casual personal conversations[20] and communications made by a client for the purpose of being imparted to others are clearly not protected by the privilege.[21] The fact of the attorney's employment, the name of the client, the address of the client, and the nature of the fee are likewise not privileged information.[22] As with other privileges, any communication involving the proposed commission of a crime or fraud will not be protected.[23]

Generally, communications made in the presence of a third person are not intended to be confidential, and the third person can testify to such communications.[24] Under these circumstances, an attorney may[25] or may not[26] be obligated to keep the communication confidential. The attorney-client privilege is broader than the privilege in other confidential relationships in that O.C.G.A. § 24-5-501 actually contemplates communications to “employees” of the attorney. The scope of the privilege has extended to an attorney's clerk, secretary, investigator, and stenographer.[27] The privilege may remain intact if the third party to the communication is a close family member of the client and the circumstances indicate that the client reasonably believed that the communication would be confidential and the presence of the relative or friend was reasonably necessary for the protection of the client's interests. Moreover, the Supreme Court of Georgia has extended the privilege to apply to confidential communications “related to matters on which legal advice is being sought, between attorneys, their agents, or their clients, and an expert engaged by the attorney to aid in the client's representation.[28] The privilege is not waived if the experts will neither serve as a witness at trial nor provide any basis for the formulation of other experts' trial testimony.”[29]

Once the attorney-client privilege attaches to communications, it is permanent and continues even after the death of the client.[30] The privilege belongs solely to the client and may not be invoked by a stranger to the attorney-client relationship.[31] Thus, after the death of a client, family members or other parties seeking to bar a former attorney's testimony may not claim privilege on behalf of the deceased unless they were parties to the attorney-client relationship or can otherwise properly stand in the place of the deceased.[32]

There is a special exception to this permanency rule in will contest cases for the attorney who drew the will for his testator client. Obviously, when a testator employs counsel to prepare a will, the communications will be privileged. However, such communications may be rendered meaningless unless the attorney is later permitted to testify in aid of the construction of the will. In such cases, the attorney is not testifying “for or against his client” and may testify to facts and communications regarding the preparation and execution of the will.[33] However, if a client consulted an attorney regarding the preparation of a will, but died before the will was prepared, the exception does not apply and the communications from the client are privileged.[34]

Another well-recognized exception to the permanency of the attorney-client privilege exists in those situations in which an attorney jointly represents two or more clients whose interests subsequently become adverse. “If two or more persons jointly consult [or retain] an attorney, the communications which either makes to the attorney are not privileged in the event of any subsequent litigation between the parties [based upon the transaction the attorney was handling for both].”[35] In such a situation, the attorney-client privilege with both of the joint parties is destroyed.

Moreover, the attorney-client privilege does not extend to communications which occur before the perpetration of a fraud or commission of a crime. Thus, privileged communications may shield crimes already committed, but the crime-fraud exception will allow the state to pierce the privilege if the communications occurred before the crime or fraud was committed.[36] However, practitioners who are appointed as a guardian ad litem should be aware that the privilege is not absolute as to their files.[37]

In such cases it would be a manifest injustice to allow the client to take advantage of the rule of privilege to the prejudice of his attorney.

Neuman v. State, 297 Ga. 501, 773 S.E.2d 716 (2015). In Neuman, the trial court allowed the state, over objection, access to doctors' notes and evaluations of the defendant and statements he made to doctors hired by his attorney to evaluate the possibility of an insanity defense. The state argued successfully at trial that the attorney-client privilege was waived by raising an insanity defense and because the defendant had signed a waiver regarding the communications with the doctors. The defense thus had to call experts it did not intend to call to testify as part of its case-in-chief. In a case of first impression, the Supreme Court reversed the conviction and opined that the communications between the doctors and the defendant were confidential despite the waiver since the waiver did not authorize the opposing party in the litigation to demand that the waiver be exercised on their behalf, but rather it was for the attorney to decide when and where to use the information.
Spence v. Hamm, 226 Ga. App. 357, 487 S.E.2d 9 (1997).
